runs.text: Display

Have students listen to the sound on the articulation video. Then display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Explain that the ai spelling stands for the /a/ sound as in train. Point to the spelling, say the letter names and sound, and have students repeat. Continue with the following spellings and words: ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
(add words with skills your students need to review)
Model
Use the first two words in the first line.
ran	rain
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?
Chorally Read

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then reblending the word together.
Provide Corrective Feedback
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Use Student Observation Form
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Extend Practice
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Chorally Respond
Display one Phonics/Syllable Card at a time. Have students chorally say the sound(s).
Mix and Repeat
When completed, mix the cards and repeat.
Then select a few cards and place in a pocket chart or on the desk.
Extend Practice
Call out the sound(s), and have students find the matching Phonics/Syllable Card with the spelling.
Repeat with the High-Frequency Word Cards.
Corrective Feedback: For high-frequency words students misread, say the word. Have students repeat, chorally spell, trace and spell, then repeat again.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the picture shows a raven, which is a type of bird. Have students find the raven in the picture.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word assist using the Define/ Example/Ask routine.
You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define: To
assist
is to help someone.
Example: As a teacher, I will
assist
you with your reading.
Ask: How can you
assist
a friend? Tell your partner about it.
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names where Rat is sleeping. (pail)
Why does Raven need Rat to assist, or help, him? Find the sentences that answer the question.
If the prefix re- means again, what does repaid mean? Why does Rat say that Raven has repaid him? Do you agree? Why or why not?
How have you assisted someone at school? What did they need help with?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Display
Display Vocabulary Picture Cards of the following: tail, baby, shade, parade.
Say
Ask students to say each pictures name. Guide students to read the sentence on the back of the card.
Build
Then guide them to build the word with Letter Cards. They can self-correct using the word on the back of the card.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Blend Words
Use the modified Lesson 1 Blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then reblending the word together.
Say
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What sounds do you hear in of? (/u/ /v/)
What letters do you see? (o-f) The word of doesnt follow the rules. This is a word for which we have to pay extra attention to in order to remember its spelling.
Spell
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Read
Then have students chorally read the word.
Write
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Provide Corrective Feedback
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Use Student Observation Form
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Extend Practice
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Read
Write each high-frequency word on a card, or display the High-Frequency Word card.
Say the word, and have students chorally read it.
Build
Then have them build the word with Letter Cards.
Write
When completed, have them write the word.
Prompt students to state and write a sentence using the word.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that an opossum is a marsupialan animal that carries its babies in a pouch, like a kangaroo.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word display using the Define/ Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define: To
display
means to show.
Example: I
display
my favorite book on the top of the bookshelf.
Ask: What would you
display
at school or home? Where would you
display
it?
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that means the same as scared. (afraid)
What body parts help the opossum survive, or live? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What does the opossum display, or show? Why does it do this?
Why does the author say opossums are great? What do you think?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Blend Words
Use the Lesson 2 blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with ai. Then have them put a box around all the words with ay.
Blending Focus
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
ran, rain, pain, paint
sad, say, pay, play
hat, hate, mate, made, mad (cumulative review)
State the Letter Card to change. For example, say:
Make ran. Add the letter i after a to make the long a spelling. What word did you make?
Word Awareness Focus
Repeat, but dont tell students which letter to change. For example, say:
Change ran to rain.
Build Words Booster (10 MIN.)
Build More Words
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
Provide Corrective Feedback
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Use Student Observation Form
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Extend Practice
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Chorally Respond
Display one Phonics/Syllable Card at a time. Have students chorally say the sound(s).
Mix and Repeat
When completed, mix the cards and repeat.
Then select a few cards and place in a pocket chart or on the desk.
Extend Practice
Call out the sound(s), and have students find the matching Phonics/Syllable Card with the spelling.
Repeat with the High-Frequency Word Cards.
Corrective Feedback: Provide phonics corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then reblending the word together.
Read
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read them.
Focus on Target Phonics Skill
Have students circle words with long a.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word strange.
Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 6 (period), 7 (exclamation mark), and 8 (question mark).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echo-read the sentences replicating your intonation.
Provide Corrective Feedback
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Use Student Observation Form
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Extend Practice
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Provide Corrective Feedback
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Use Student Observation Form
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Extend Practice
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
